thread.title: ACCC may torpedo $146b global beer deal to prevent 'cosy duopoly'
thread.title_full: ACCC may torpedo $146b global beer deal to prevent 'cosy duopoly'

author: Lincoln Feast
title: ACCC may torpedo $146b global beer deal to prevent 'cosy duopoly'
text:
Return to video Video settings Please Log in to update your video settings
Video will begin in 5 seconds.
Don't play Play now More video Recommended Why house prices are so high

Mal Maiden: Beer giants merge

Replay video Return to video Video settings Please Log in to update your video settings
Global beer market shrinks SAB Miller has given the nod to a takeover bid by Anheuser-Busch InBev valued at $A145 billion
PT0M55S 620 349 Autoplay On Off Video feedback Video settings Australian regulators are likely to raise concerns over the planned $146 billion takeover of SABMiller by rival Anheuser-Busch InBev, wary of its impact on competition in the local beer market.
After a long courtship, SABMiller agreed on Tuesday to a deal that would rank among the top five mergers in history , creating a global beer behemoth that would brew one in every three beers worldwide.
In Australia, the takeover would combine the country's biggest and third-biggest brewers to control around 46 per cent of Australasia's 2 billion litre beer market, according to figures from Euromonitor.
With brands including Victoria Bitter and Carlton Draught, SABMiller is already Australia's biggest brewer. Photo: Louie Douvis
That's a smaller percentage than some other markets such as the United States, Peru and Argentina. But the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) has long been wary of deals where the top three players are cut to two, says Allan Fels, a former chairman of the commission.
Advertisement "This deal will not have an easy ride through the ACCC," said Fels. "The battle between second and third position often stimulates competition more generally in the market... In this case it's not clear there is a lot of surrounding competition, and therefore it could be that a cosy duopoly emerges."
With brands including Victoria Bitter and Carlton Draught, SABMiller is Australia's biggest brewer with around 38 per cent market share. It's followed closely by Kirin Holdings, which claims 32 per cent of the market with its stable of beers including local favourites XXXX and Toohey's.
"No easy ride": Former ACCC chairman Allan Fels. Photo: Alex Ellinghausen
After AB InBev, which has 8.5 per cent of the local beer market with brands such as Corona and Becks, the next biggest brewer, privately owned Coopers Brewery, has just a 3.6 per cent share.
Brewing opposition "If there is evidence that the No. 3 is likely to grow and be an effective competitive constraint against the big two, then that would suggest that there could be concerns," said one competition lawyer, who asked not to be identified.
The merger is expected to have repercussions for the rest of the global beer industry, particularly in the United States where the two companies would own about 70 per cent of the beer market unless they sell off some assets.
Analysts say the combined group might also have to sell interests in China, where SABMiller's CR Snow joint venture with China Resources Enterprise is the market leader.
To get the deal over the line, the beer giants may even have to get rid of Snow, the best-selling beer on the planet, they say.
"It's conceivable that the merger is blocked internationally," said Fels, who was chairman of the ACCC until 2003 and is now an economics professor at the University of Melbourne.
"But if it's not, if it sails through overseas but is blocked here, they'd have to consider calling off this part of the transaction."
Reuters
